DISCOURS DE MICHEL ROCARD
CEREMONIE “DOCTORAT HONORIS CAUSA”
AMERICAN UNIVERSITY OF PARIS

Vendredi 26 mai 2006

It is an honor for me to be made Doctor Honoris Causa of your University, for which I thank

Mr. President, dear friends,

you warmly.

This distinction has naturally a private meaning : I understand that my intellectual or
governmental contribution to Franco or Europeo-American relations has held your attention,

which makes me happy and validates in a way some of my hypotheses or assumptions.

But there is also a political meaning to your decision. Franco American relations have been
sometimes euphoric, and frequently difﬁcult if not disastrous. We are not exactly in the best

period, even if we have known much worse times three years ago.

Naturally, being the American University in Paris, you know about all this much more than
any other institution, and l am sure this experience passes from the collective body to all
concerned individuals. Delivering diplomas to French people is after all a very classical
activity of your institution, but you are very well aware that its meaning in France cannot be

considered only private, or limited to Academic signiﬁcance.

There is in each one of our two countries a deep knowledge of the importance, and length, and
density of our historical ties, as well as some annoyance, some irritation about the other.

France shows evidently, every day, some sort of arrogance coming from her great past, from
the fact that she has led the world some four centuries ago, and that her language, culture and '
patrimony ﬁgure among the best of the world. Seen from an American point of view, by

citizens whose country lead effectively the world today and has an undisputed leadership as

 

well in technologies as in culture, this French self conﬁdence is by all means irritating. I do
know we should more discreetly and among ourselves exclusively cry on the loss of our

former empire ! The reference to Lafayette is now a threadbare argument.

On the reverse, America seen from France has something of an ungrateful child. The United
States uses little courtesy precautions to let us understand that our advices have no more any
weight nor importance. Personally I do think this is quite natural, corresponds to the way
things are, and I don’t mind. But most of my co-citizens don’t take it that way and feel
offended. Growing old is an art which is difﬁcult to leam for individuals as well as for
nations. A few of you, but unfortunately sometimes in govemment, make public that their
measure of friendship is correlated with the enthusiasm we display in following your
decisions and opinions. I do admit this is a mistake in understanding what really is friendship,
but'I do admit as well that the balance of forces does not facilitate another attitude, and that

we should satisfy ourselves with a less demanding relation.

 

These difﬁculties in mutual understanding are relatively recent. After Louis the XVIth
decision to go to war with Britain in order to help you conquering your independence, and the
signature in Paris in 1776 of the treaty which creates the international recognition of the
United States of America, our relations have been absolutely without a cloud for a hundred

and sixty years, a long period in human history. The deterioration is post world war II.

It might not be useless, on each side, t0 recall the main factors which have produced this
detrimental result. A better knowledge in each country of the element which has been most

inj urious to the depth of our relations in the other might help to diminish the sorrow.

Seen from the French side, the fact that in 1944, after having successfully landed, and freed
our territory, the American government did not consider necessary to restore a country named
France with independent authorities has been felt as an insult. For a short time we were no
more France, but AMGOT, American Military Govemment of Occupied Territories, with the
dollar as currency. The banknotes were printed. This did not last long. Churchill immediately
agreed with De Gaulle that this was not the good solution and made sufﬁcient pressure on
Roosevelt to get rid of that issue. But symbolically the damage was done, and all the political
elites of the liberated country harbored, for long, a deep resentment. Distrust and suspicion

appeared in our relations.

 

The other way round, it is the nature and the origin of the so-called French anti—Americanism
which should be questioned. After the initial shock I just alluded to, the rancor remained
limited to the Gaullist circles. But we had another source of anti-American xenophobia. For
our misfortune, France has inherited from the prewar and war periods a very powerful and
very Stalinist communist party. As soon as 1933 Maurice Thorez, his newly elected Secretary
General, decided to play an extremely nationalist card. And thanks to Nazi occupation the
communist party succeeded in building, through a massive and courageous participation in the
resistance, an extremely patriotic image which afterwards was used to serve a frantic anti-
American attitude. We know ourselves, we have polls, we study public opinion. The French
anti-Americanism which comes from these two belongings rarely if ever exceeded 40 %
among French citizens. But that was too much for American perception, after all the United
States had liberated us, we should be grateful. So, instead of a thorough analysis and a
recognition of majoritarian sympathy, we just got a global mistrust. Conditions are then
fulfllled to produce when all this is outstripped by a real collective disagreement, for instance
about our Algerian war or yours in Iraq, a real and deep feeling of collective disapproval if
not rej ection. Such appreciations have generally proved themselves over estir/natedïafterwards.

Having chosen the American University in Paris, you belong to the highly se e efi category
of witnesses of the Franco American friendship. So do I by a long conviction and today’s
distinction. This creates for us the duty to analyze any punctual disagreement, to get it rid of
subjective and historically dated fantasies, and ﬁnally to make on any occasion the difference
between opinions on political decisions and the reality of a deeply rooted ancient and
permanent relation of solidarity, friendship and of common destiny as founding democracies.
This should even be compatible with an improvement of our mutual listening capacities. After
all our two countries are rich of an enormous experience, different for each, but which

probably deserves to be presented to the other and examined, in mutual interest.

I insist on this necessity to rid our relation from temporary political pollutions because I am
worried. The evolution of our respective cultural models is diverging. The enormous power of
the United States is disproportionate to its short history. Some of your goveming authorities
seem to take pleasure in using force, whereas military power should always be used with self

restriction and modesty.

 

On our side, the extreme weakness is no better advisor.

And, which is more, our basic social attitudes, our anthropological cultures, as sociologists
would say, are not converging either. Concerning the use of natural resources, or the accepted
degree of social cruelty that market economy implies, we behave differently, and apparently
more and more differently. My friend Jeremy Riﬂ<in has recently published a fascinating
book, called “The European dream”, which enlightens all that. To preserve our relation the

minimum is to take ﬁill conscience of these evolutions and understand them.

All of you, newly graduated members of the American University in Paris, have had the
chance of discovering and experimenting the two cultures of our countries. Therefore, you
have now a signiﬁcant role to play in order to facilitate comprehension, increase mutual

knowledge, and develop conﬁdent relations between the United States and France.

In front of the fast growing Asia, of the awakening of Russia, all regions with which mutual
understanding is not established in advance, I do think there is an absolute necessity of
solidarity between western democratic nations. It cannot result only of political opportunity or
even necessity. It has to rely on mutual respect, knowledge and conﬁdence, all commodities

that can be provided by a good old rusty but faithful friendship.
